page.title: 04Marshside Marsh Birds
page.content: There are lots of different birds on the marsh. The most common bird is the lapwing. All these birds make their nests on the ground. They lay about 3 or 4 eggs and half survive. The other eggs get eaten by predators which are weasels, rats and larger birds. About three weeks later the chicks get their body feathers. Many of the birds are migrating from other countries such as Africa, the Arctic and Iceland. They use the sun and magnetic forces. They started to migrate to Marshside Marsh because there is a lot of food there. The birds eat snail-like creatures and small worms with only scientific names. The rarest birds on the marsh are the redfooted falcon, sandpiper, marsh harrier, knight heron and the squaco heron.
